GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 93.01 OUTSIDE BURNING.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to dispose of any trash, garbage, or refuse of
any kind by outside burning within the corporate limits of the village or to
undertake or permit any outside burning except under the following conditions.
      (1)   It shall be lawful to do outside cooking with charcoal fuel in
appropriate burners or barbecue pits constructed for that purpose.
      (2)   The Mayor is hereby authorized to lift the ban on burning outside
for a period of not more than four weeks, once in the Spring and once in the
Fall of the year, and thereby permit the burning of leaves, garden refuse, and
shrub clippings, in a manner however that will not be hazardous or injurious to
other property.
      (3)   Outside burning of any kind other than that authorized in this
section shall be permitted only after receiving written permission from the
Fire Control Committee of the village.
   (B)   No outside burning permitted under this section or through the action
of the Fire Control Committee shall be construed as authorizing or making
lawful any such burning which is prohibited under applicable federal or state
laws or regulations which are interpreted to be superior to or to supercede
this section.
(Prior Code, § 93.01) (Ord. 1598, passed 11-18-1952; Ord. 72-7, passed 2-8-
1972) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.02 PAPER BALLOONS WITH FLAME.
   It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale or give away a paper balloon
to which a burning light or flame may be attached, or to release into the air
any such balloon with burning light or flame.
(Prior Code, § 93.02) Penalty, see §
93.99
INFLAMMABLE OR COMBUSTIBLE MATERIALS
§ 93.15 REMOVAL OF INFLAMMABLES OR OBSTRUCTIONS.
   Any inflammable or combustible materials not arranged or stored in a manner
affording reasonable safety against fire, or any matter stored or arranged so
as to impede or prevent access to, or exit from, said premises in case of fire,
shall be ordered removed or rearranged in such manner as to eliminate any fire
hazard. Such order shall be in writing and delivered to the owner, lessee, or
occupant of said premises, or if he or she cannot be found, said order shall be
posted on the door of said premises.
(Prior Code, § 93.15) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.16 FAULTY EQUIPMENT; ORDER OF ABATEMENT.
   If the units or equipment mentioned in §
93.19 are defective, so as to constitute a fire hazard, such officer shall
cause to be delivered to the owner, lessee, or occupant, or if he or she cannot
be found, to be posted on the front door of said premises a written order
setting forth the nature of defects and ordering abatement of such condition
within a specified time.
(Prior Code, § 93.16)
§ 93.17 FIREPROOF WASTE RECEPTACLES.
   Waste paper, ashes, oil rags, waste rags, excelsior, or any material of a
similar hazardous nature shall not be accumulated in any cellar or any other
portion of any building of any kind, and proper fireproof receptacles shall be
provided for such hazardous materials.
(Prior Code, § 93.17) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.18 THROWING INFLAMMABLE MATERIALS IN STREETS; SUPPRESSION COSTS.
   It shall be unlawful for anyone to throw, dump, scatter, or otherwise
deposit papers, cardboard, or other inflammable matter on the streets or alleys
of the village, or onto private property in the open, except into fireproof
containers.
(Prior Code, § 93.18) (Ord. 1503, passed 9-20-1949) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.19 FIRE INSPECTION.
   The Fire Chief or any member of the Fire Department is hereby authorized and
empowered, at any and all reasonable times and, upon complaint or information,
shall be required to enter and inspect any premises, building, or structure
within the village with regard to the presence, arrangement, or deposit of
inflammable or combustible materials or matter which may constitute a fire
hazard or create danger in case of fire, and further to inspect the condition
of all heat producing or electrical units or equipment in such premises.
(Prior Code, § 93.19)
§ 93.20 ENFORCEMENT OF ORDER.
   Any order made pursuant to §§
93.15 and
93.16 which is not appealed, or which is sustained by the Village
Administrator, shall be complied with by the owner, lessee, or occupant within
the time specified in such order. If said order is not fully complied with, the
Fire Chief may cause such order to be complied with by the Fire Department, may
otherwise remove or abate such fire hazard, or may certify such non-compliance
to the Village Solicitor for proper court action. Proceeding under this section
shall not relieve any party defendant from criminal prosecution or punishment
under this code, or any other criminal law, or ordinance in force, within the
village. Each day’s continued violation of a lawful order issued under this
chapter shall constitute a separate offense.
(Prior Code, § 93.20) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.21 APPEALS.
   Any owner, lessee, or occupant, within 24 hours after the written order has
been given, as provided in §§
93.15 and
93.16, may appeal to the Village Administrator who shall hear such appeal and
render his or her decision, which shall be final.
(Prior Code, § 93.21)
FIREWORKS AND EXPLOSIVES
§ 93.35 PERMIT TO USE FIREWORKS.
   (A)   An exhibitor of fireworks licensed under R.C. §§ 3743.50 through
3743.55 who wishes to conduct a public fireworks exhibition shall apply for
approval to conduct the exhibition to the Fire Chief or Fire Prevention Officer
and to the Police Chief or other similar chief law enforcement officer, or the
designee of the Police Chief or other similar chief law enforcement officer,
having jurisdiction over the premises.
   (B)   The approval required by division (A) of this section shall be
evidenced by the Fire Chief or Fire Prevention Officer and by the Police Chief
or other similar chief law enforcement officer, or the designee of the Police
Chief or similar chief law enforcement officer, signing a permit for the
exhibition. Any exhibitor of fireworks who wishes to conduct a public fireworks
exhibition may obtain a copy of the form from the State Fire Marshal or, if
available, from the Fire Chief, a Fire Prevention Officer, the Police Chief, or
other similar chief law enforcement officer, or a designee of the Police Chief
or other similar chief law enforcement officer.
   (C)   Before a permit is signed and issued to a licensed exhibitor of
fireworks, the Fire Chief, or Fire Prevention Officer, in consultation with the
Police Chief or other similar chief law enforcement officer, or the designee of
the Police Chief or other similar chief law enforcement officer, shall inspect
the premises on which the exhibition will take place and shall determine that,
in fact, the applicant for the permit is a licensed exhibitor of fireworks.
Each applicant shall show his or her license as an exhibitor of fireworks to
the Fire Chief or Fire Prevention Officer.
   (D)   The Fire Chief or Fire Prevention Officer and the Police Chief or
other similar chief law enforcement officer, or the designee of the Police
Chief or other similar chief law enforcement officer, shall give approval to
conduct a public fireworks exhibition only if satisfied, based on the
inspection, that the premises on which the exhibition will be conducted allow
the exhibitor to comply with the rules adopted by the State Fire Marshal
pursuant to R.C. § 3743.53(B) and (E) and that the applicant is, in fact, a
licensed exhibitor of fireworks. The Fire Chief or Fire Prevention Officer, in
consultation with the Police Chief or other similar chief law enforcement
officer or with the designee of the Police Chief or other similar chief law
enforcement officer, may inspect the premises immediately prior to the
exhibition to determine if the exhibitor has complied with the rules, and may
revoke a permit for noncompliance with the rules.
   (E)   If the legislative authority has prescribed a fee for the issuance of
a permit for a public fireworks exhibition, the Fire Chief or Fire Prevention
Officer and Police Chief or other similar chief law enforcement officer, or
their designee, shall not issue a permit until the exhibitor pays the requisite
fee.
   (F)   Each exhibitor shall provide an indemnity bond in the amount of at
least $1,000,000 with surety satisfactory to the Fire Chief or Fire Prevention
Officer and to the Police Chief or other similar chief law enforcement officer,
or the designee of the Police Chief or other similar chief law enforcement
officer, conditioned for the payment of all final judgments that may be
rendered against the exhibitor on account of injury, death, or loss to person
or property emanating from the fireworks exhibitor, or proof of insurance
coverage of at least $1,000,000 for liability arising from injury, death, or
loss of persons or property emanating from the fireworks exhibition. The
legislative authority may require the exhibitor to provide an indemnity bond or
proof of insurance coverage in amounts greater than those required by this
division. The Fire Chief or Fire Prevention Officer and Police Chief or other
similar chief law enforcement officer, or their designee, shall not issue a
permit until the exhibitor provides the bond or proof of the insurance coverage
required by this division or by the legislative authority.
   (G)   Each permit for a fireworks exhibition issued by the Fire Chief or
Fire Prevention Officer and by the Police Chief or other similar chief law
enforcement officer, or the designee of the Police Chief or other similar chief
law enforcement officer, shall contain a distinct number, designate the
municipality, and identify the certified fire safety inspector, Fire Chief, or
Fire Prevention Officer who will be present before, during and after the
exhibition, where appropriate. A copy of each permit issued shall be forwarded
by the Fire Chief or Fire Prevention Officer and by the Police Chief or other
similar chief law enforcement officer, or designee of the Police Chief or other
similar chief law enforcement officer, issuing it to the State Fire Marshal. A
permit is not transferable or assignable.
   (H)   The Fire Chief or Fire Prevention Officer and Police Chief or other
similar chief law enforcement officer, or designee of the Police Chief or other
similar chief law enforcement officer, shall keep a record of issued permits
for fireworks exhibitions. In this list, the Fire Chief, Fire Prevention
Officer, Police Chief, or other similar chief law enforcement officer, or
designee of the Police Chief or other similar chief law enforcement officer,
shall list the name of the exhibitor, his or her license number, the premises
on which the exhibition will be conducted, the date and time of the exhibition,
and the number and political subdivision designation of the permit issued to
the exhibitor for the exhibition.
   (I)   The legislative authority shall require that a certified fire safety
inspector, Fire Chief, or Fire Prevention Officer be present before, during and
after the exhibition, and shall require the certified fire safety inspector,
Fire Chief, or Fire Prevention Officer to inspect the premises where the
exhibition is to take place and determine whether the exhibition is in
compliance with this chapter and R.C. Chapter 3743.
(R.C. § 3743.54(B) - (F)) (Prior Code, § 93.35) Penalty, see §
93.99
Statutory reference:
   Notice of fireworks incident, see R.C. § 3743.541.
§ 93.36 STORAGE OF EXPLOSIVES.
   It shall be unlawful to store at any time in any powder house or magazine
within the village limits a quantity of gunpowder or other similar explosive
weighing in excess of 100 pounds.
(Prior Code, § 93.36) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.37 SALE OF EXPLOSIVES TO MINORS.
   It shall be unlawful to sell, offer for sale, or give away to a minor any
explosive cap, cartridge, shell, guncotton, or other similar article containing
explosives.
(Prior Code, § 93.37) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.38 BLASTING PERMIT.
   No person shall cause a blast to occur within the village without making
application in writing beforehand, setting forth the exact nature of the
intended operation and receiving a permit to blast from the Mayor. The Mayor
before granting such permit may require the applicant to provide a bond to
indemnify the village and all other persons against injury or damages which
might result from the proposed blasting.
(Prior Code, § 93.38) Penalty, see §
93.99
ADMINISTRATION
§ 93.50 FIRE CONTROL COMMITTEE.
   (A)   There is hereby created the Fire Control Committee of the village
which shall consist of the Mayor, Village Administrator, and Fire Chief, with
the Mayor to act as chairperson. The duties of the Fire Control Committee shall
be to receive, consider, and act upon all written applications to conduct
outside burning operations of any type not expressly permitted in §
93.01(A)(1) and (A)(2), and to deny such applications or issue permits to burn
under the following guidelines.
      (1)   Garbage, tires, and trash other than wood, tree cuttings, logs, or
other brush cutting and leaves may not be permitted to be burned under any
circumstances, nor shall the burning of any other substance that creates
noxious or hazardous fumes be permitted.
      (2)   No permit to burn shall be granted that could be hazardous to life,
limb, or property and shall be permitted only under fire safety guidelines
established by the Fire Control Committee and approved by the Fire Chief.
      (3)   A permit to burn for the purpose of disposing of the aforesaid
permissible types of materials so as to avoid the necessity of other possible
methods of disposal shall be granted only if a majority of the Fire Control
Committee determines that the public good requires it.
      (4)   The Fire Control Committee may give permits for burning of fires
for recreational or ceremonial purposes and outdoor cooking of food beyond that
allowed without permit under §
93.01(A)(1).
(Prior Code, § 93.50) (Ord. 1598, passed 11-18-1952; Ord. 72-7, passed 2-8-
1972)
§ 93.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter, for which another
penalty is not specifically provided, shall be fined not more than $100 for
each offense.
   (B)   In addition, to the above penalty, anyone found guilty of violating §
93.18 shall pay the cost of the prosecution, and if the Fire Department is
summoned to quell a fire due in the first place to a violation of this section,
the person so responsible for the presence or burning of the matter shall be
fined in addition to the above fine the cost of the payroll of the Volunteer
Fire Department for that particular fire.
(Prior Code, § 93.99) (Ord. 1503, passed 9-20-1949)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 94.01 MAINTAINING CERTAIN NUISANCES.
   (A)   No person shall erect, continue to use, or maintain a building,
structure, or place for the exercise of a trade, employment, or business or for
keeping or feeding an animal which, by occasioning noxious exhalations or
noisome or offensive smells, becomes injurious to the health, comfort, or
property of individuals or of the public.
   (B)   No person shall cause or allow offal, filth, or noisome substances to
be collected or remain in any place to the damage or prejudice of others or of
the public.
   (C)   No person shall unlawfully obstruct or impede the passage of a
navigable river, harbor, or collection of water, or corrupt or render
unwholesome or impure a watercourse, stream of water, or unlawfully divert such
watercourse from its natural course or state to the injury or prejudice of
others.
   (D)   Persons who are engaged in agriculture-related activities, as
“agriculture” is defined in R.C. § 519.01, and who are conducting those
activities outside the municipality, in accordance with generally accepted
agricultural practices, and in such a manner so as not to have a substantial,
adverse effect on the public health, safety, or welfare, are exempt from
divisions (A) and (B) above and from any ordinances, resolutions, rules, or
other enactments of the municipality that prohibit excessive noise.
(R.C. § 3767.13)
   (E)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third
degree.
(R.C. § 3767.99(C))
WEEDS AND RANK VEGETATION; LITTER
§ 94.15 PROPERTY TO BE KEPT FREE AND CLEAR OF NOXIOUS WEEDS AND RANK
VEGETATION.
   Any person owning or having charge of land within the village, shall keep
said property free and clear from all noxious weeds and rank vegetation, and
shall be required to keep all such weeds and vegetation on the land owned or
controlled by him or her a maximum of 12 inches in height at all times.
(Prior Code, § 94.01) (Ord. 2004-12, passed 5-4-2004; Ord. 12-20, passed 6-19-
2012; Ord. 19-09, passed 5-21-2019) Penalty, see §
94.99 
§ 94.16 NOTICE TO OWNER TO CUT NOXIOUS WEEDS, REMOVE LITTER; SERVICE.
   (A)   Upon written information that noxious weeds are growing on lands in
the municipality and are about to spread or mature seeds, the legislative
authority shall cause written notice to be served on the owner, lessee, agent,
or tenant having charge of such land, notifying him or her that noxious weeds
are growing on such lands and that they must be cut and destroyed within five
days after service of such notice.
   (B)   Upon a finding by the legislative authority that litter has been
placed on lands in a municipality, and has not been removed, and constitutes a
detriment to public health, the legislative authority shall cause a written
notice to be served upon the owner and, if different, upon the lessee, agent,
or tenant having charge of the littered land, notifying him or her that litter
is on the land, and that it must be collected and removed within 15 days after
the service of the notice.
   (C)   As used in this section and §
94.18, LITTER includes any garbage, waste, peelings of vegetables or fruits,
rubbish, ashes, cans, bottles, wire, paper, cartons, boxes, parts of
automobiles, wagons, furniture, glass, oil of an unsightly or unsanitary
nature, or anything else of an unsightly or unsanitary nature.
   (D)   If the owner or other person having charge of the land is a
nonresident of the municipality whose address is known, the notice shall be
sent to his or her address by certified mail. If the address of the owner or
other person having charge of the land is unknown it is sufficient to publish
the notice once in a newspaper of general circulation in the county.
   (E)   This section does not apply to land being used under a municipal
building or construction permit or license, a municipal permit or license, or a
conditional zoning permit or variance to operate a junkyard, scrap metal
processing facility, or similar business, or a permit or license issued
pursuant to R.C. Chapter 3734, R.C. §§ 4737.05 through 4737.12, or R.C. Chapter
6111.
(R.C. § 731.51)
§ 94.17 FEES FOR SERVICE AND RETURN.
   The Police Chief, any police officer, or Clerk of the legislative authority
may make service and return of the notice provided for in §
94.16 and shall be allowed the same fees as that provided for service and
return of summons in civil cases before a magistrate.
(R.C. § 731.52)
§ 94.18 PROCEDURE WHEN OWNER FAILS TO COMPLY WITH NOTICE.
   If the owner, lessee, agent, or tenant having charge of the lands mentioned
in §
94.16 fails to comply with the notice required by such section, the Legislative
Authority shall cause such noxious weeds to be cut and destroyed or such litter
removed and may employ the necessary labor to perform the task. All expenses
incurred shall, when approved by the legislative authority, be paid out of the
money in the treasury of the municipality not otherwise appropriated.
(R.C. § 731.53)
§ 94.19 WRITTEN RETURN TO COUNTY AUDITOR; AMOUNT AS A LIEN UPON PROPERTY.
   The legislative authority shall make a written return to the County Auditor
of their action under §§
94.16,
94.17, and
94.18, with a statement of the charges for their services, the amount paid for
labor, the fees of the officers serving the notices, and a proper description
of the premises. These amounts, when allowed, shall be entered upon the tax
duplicate and be a lien upon such lands from and after the date of entry and be
collected as other taxes and returned to the municipality with the General
Fund.
(R.C. § 731.54)
LITTER ON PUBLIC OR PRIVATE PROPERTY OR IN STATE WATERS
§ 94.30 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CASUAL PASSERBY. A person who does not have depositing litter in a litter
receptacle as his or her primary reason for traveling to or by the property on
which the litter receptacle is located.
   DEPOSIT. To throw, drop, discard, or place.
   LITTER. Garbage, trash, waste, rubbish, ashes, cans, bottles, wire, paper,
cartons, boxes, automobile parts, furniture, glass, or anything else of an
unsightly or unsanitary nature.
   LITTER RECEPTACLE. A dumpster, trash can, trash bin, garbage can, or similar
container in which litter is deposited for removal.
   PUBLIC PROPERTY. Includes any private property open to the public for the
conduct of business, the provision of a service, or upon the payment of a fee
but does not include any private property to which the public otherwise does
not have a right of access.
(Prior Code, § 94.15) (Ord. 95-29, passed 9-26-1995)
§ 94.31 LITTERING RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   No person, regardless of intent, shall deposit litter or cause litter
to be deposited on any public property, on private property not owned by him or
her, or in or on waters of the state unless one of the following applies:
      (1)   The person is directed to do so by a public official as part of a
litter collection drive;
      (2)   Except as provided in division (B) of this section, the person
deposits the litter in a litter receptacle in a manner that prevents its being
carried away by the elements; or
      (3)   The person is issued a permit or license covering the litter
pursuant to R.C. Chapter 3734 or Chapter 6111.
   (B)   No person, without privilege to do so, shall knowingly deposit litter,
or cause it to be deposited, in a litter receptacle located on any public
property or on any private property not owned by him or her unless one of the
following applies:
      (1)   The litter was generated or located on the property on which the
litter receptacle is located;
      (2)   The person is directed to do so by a public official as part of a
litter collection drive;
      (3)   The person is directed to do so by a person whom he or she
reasonably believes to have the privilege to use the litter receptacle; or
      (4)   The litter consists of any of the following:
         (a)   The contents of a litter bag or container of a type and size
customarily carried and used in a motor vehicle;
         (b)   The contents of an ash tray of a type customarily installed or
carried and used in a motor vehicle;
         (c)   Beverage containers and food sacks, wrappings, and containers of
a type and in an amount that reasonably may be expected to be generated during
routine commuting or business or recreational travel by a motor vehicle; or
         (d)   Beverage containers, food sacks, wrappings, containers, and
other materials of a type and in an amount that reasonably may be expected to
be generated during a routine day by a person and deposited in a litter
receptacle by a casual passerby.
(Prior Code, § 94.16) (Ord. 95-29, passed 9-26-1995) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.32 ENFORCEMENT.
   This subchapter may be enforced by any sheriff, deputy sheriff, village
police officer, wildlife officer, park officer, forest officer, preserve
officer, conservancy district police officer, inspector of nuisances of a
county, or any other law enforcement officer within his or her jurisdiction.
(Prior Code, § 94.17) (Ord. 95-29, passed 9-26-1995)
REFUSE
§ 94.45 ABANDONED REFRIGERATORS.
   (A)   No person shall abandon, discard, or knowingly permit to remain on
premises under the person’s control, in a place accessible to children, any
abandoned or discarded icebox, refrigerator, or other airtight or semi-airtight
container which has a capacity of 1.5 cubic feet or more and an opening of 50
square inches or more and which has a door or lid equipped with a hinge, latch,
or other fastening device capable of securing such door or lid, without
rendering the equipment harmless to human life by removing such hinges, latches
or other hardware which may cause a person to be confined therein. This section
shall not apply to an icebox, refrigerator or other airtight or semi-airtight
container located in that part of a building occupied by a dealer, warehouse or
repairer.
(R.C. § 3767.29)
   (B)   Whoever violates this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the
fourth degree.
(R.C. § 3767.99(B))
MOBILE HOMES
§ 94.55 MOBILE HOMES DEEMED A NUISANCE.
   (A)   For purposes of this section, MOBILE HOME shall have the same meaning
as that set forth in §
154.006.
   (B)   No person shall cause or allow any uninhabited mobile home to remain
on any lands in the village for a period of time in excess of six months. Any
such mobile home is hereby declared to be a nuisance, and upon information and
investigation, the Village Administrator shall cause written notice to be
served upon the owner of the land and, if different, the owner of the mobile
home, notifying such person(s) that the mobile home shall be removed from the
land within 60 days after the service of the notice.
   (C)   Notice shall be sent by certified mail. If the address of an owner is
unknown, it is sufficient to post the notice upon the primary structure located
on the land, or, if there is no such structure, then a conspicuous place
thereon.
   (D)   If the owner fails to comply with the notice provided by division (B)
of this section, the Village Administrator shall cause such mobile home to be
removed, and may employ the necessary labor to perform the task. All expenses
incurred by the village shall, when approved by Village Council, be paid out of
monies in the treasury of the village not otherwise appropriated.
   (E)   Any owner who fails to comply with the notice provided by division (B)
of this section, is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. Each day’s violation shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Prior Code, § 94.35) (Ord. 10-03, passed 6-18-2010) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter, for which another
penalty is not already provided, shall be guilty of a fourth degree
misdemeanor.
(Prior Code, § 94.99)
   (B)   Whoever violates any provision of §
94.31 shall be guilty of littering, a misdemeanor, and subject to a fine of not
more than $500.
(Prior Code, § 94.16)
(Ord. 92-42, passed 8-18-1992; Ord. 95-29, passed 9-26-1995; Ord. 2004-12,
passed 5-4-2004; Ord. 06-33, passed 9-19-2006)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 95.01 APPLICATION OF RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (A)   The following rules and regulations are hereby adopted as applicable
to those parks and playgrounds operated and controlled by the village.
   (B)   This subchapter shall be in addition to and shall complement any other
laws or regulations pertaining to the use of such parks and playgrounds that
now or hereafter exist and shall not be considered to be exclusive in their
application.
(Prior Code, § 95.01) (Ord. 76-6, passed 3-16-1976)
§ 95.02 POSTING OF RULES.
   Rules shall be posted at the basketball courts.
(Prior Code, § 95.02) (Ord. 76-6, passed 3-16-1976)
§ 95.03 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   All playgrounds excepting Hammond Park shall be open only between dawn to
dusk, except on Sundays, when the opening hours shall be from 1:00 p.m. to
dusk.
(Prior Code, § 95.03) (Ord. 76-6, passed 3-16-1976; Ord. 09-05, passed 3-17-
2009)
§ 95.04 RESTRICTIONS ON USE OF CERTAIN PLAYGROUND FACILITIES.
   (A)   Only village school student residents shall be permitted to use
playground facilities excepting the tennis courts both at 18th Street and
Hammond Park which may also be used by adults who are residents of the village.
The aforesaid restrictions relating to use by residents shall not apply to the
13th Street ball park or to Hammond Park other than the tennis courts located
in Hammond Park. Any person who is a non-resident of the village shall be
permitted to use the aforesaid facilities only if accompanied by a village
resident of the proper age as his or her guest, and said resident host shall be
responsible for the conduct of the non-resident guest in the use of said
facilities.
   (B)   Any use by any person of said playground in violation of the aforesaid
regulations shall be a trespass.
(Prior Code, § 95.04) (Ord. 76-6, passed 3-16-1976) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.05 CLOSING PLAYGROUND AREA UPON EMERGENCY CONDITIONS.
   The Police Department shall have the power to close any court in said
playground or the playground entirely in the event of an emergency or
disturbance thereon until the disturbance or other emergency condition has been
abated, and any use of said facility by any person during such closures shall
be deemed to be a trespass.
(Prior Code, § 95.05) (Ord. 76-6, passed 3-16-1976) Penalty, see §
95.99  
BROADWAY PARK
§ 95.15 CERTAIN ACTIVITIES PROHIBITED.
   The following activities are prohibited in the confines of the grassy areas
of Broadway Park between Ninth Street and Fifth Street and between the easterly
and westerly bound lanes of Broadway:
   (A)   No person shall operate any type of vehicle upon said grassy area.
Such prohibition includes bicycles, horse-drawn vehicles, and any type of motor
driven vehicle other than for maintenance purposes; and
   (B)   Active playing involving two or more persons is prohibited. Such
playing includes such things as football, basketball, baseball, frisbee
throwing, racing, and any other activities of a similar nature.
(Prior Code, § 95.15) (Ord. 80-24, passed 7-3-1980) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.16 ERECTION OR POSTING OF SIGNS OTHER THAN STREET SIGNS AND MARKERS
PROHIBITED.
   The posting or erection, either on posts or trees, of signs or announcements
of any type or variety is hereby prohibited in Broadway Park. This section,
however, shall not prohibit the erection or maintenance by the village of
official street signs and markers in said area.
(Prior Code, § 95.16) (Ord. 80-28, passed 8-5-1980) Penalty, see §
95.99
HAMMOND PARK
§ 95.30 FEE FOR USE OF PAVILION.
   (A)   A fee in the sum of $25 is hereby established for the private
reservation and use of the Hammond Park pavilion.
   (B)   Persons reserving private use of the Hammond Park pavilion shall be
required to proffer the fee at the time the reservation is made.
(Ord. 22-04, passed 4-5-2022)
§ 95.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   The penalty for any violation of §§
95.01 through
95.05 shall be a fine of not to exceed $50 for a first offense or $100 for a
second or subsequent offense, and in addition thereto upon the conviction of a
third offense, such party shall be denied admittance to such facility entirely.
   (B)   Any person or persons convicted of such violation of §
95.15 shall be subject to a fine of not less than $50 nor more than $200 for
each offense.
   (C)   Any person or persons convicted of such violation of §
95.16 shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
(Prior Code, § 95.99) (Ord. 76-6, passed 3-16-1976; Ord. 80-24, passed 7-3-
1980; Ord. 80-28, passed 8-5-1980)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 96.01 GRADES OF STREETS.
   The grade of any street shall refer to the elevation of the top or upper
surface of either of its curbs at any series of points thereon. The Village
Administrator may establish such grade or grades as provided in this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 96.01)
§ 96.02 CONDITIONS PRECEDENT TO IMPROVING STREETS.
   No department of the village shall accept, lay out, open, improve, grade,
pave, curb, or light any street or other way or any sidewalk thereon or
adjacent thereto unless such street or way shall have been accepted or opened;
or otherwise shall have received the legal status of a public street or way, or
unless such street or way corresponds in location and extent with a street or
way shown on a recorded plat which shall have been legally accepted by the
Village Council.
(Prior Code, § 96.02)
OBSTRUCTIONS
§ 96.15 EXCAVATING, LEAVING MUD ON, OR BUILDING FENCE ON HIGHWAY.
   (A)   No person shall dig up, remove, excavate, or place any earth or mud
upon any portion of any public highway, or build a fence upon the same without
authority to do so. Each day that such person continues to dig up, remove, or
excavate any portion of the public highway constitutes a separate offense.
   (B)   No person shall obstruct any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public
way in the village, by erecting thereon any fence or building, or permitting
any fence or building to remain thereon. Each day that any such fence or
building is permitted to remain upon such public way, shall be deemed a
separate offense.
(Prior Code, § 96.15) Penalty, see §
96.99
§ 96.16 UNLOADING MATERIALS ON STREETS AND SIDEWALKS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to unload any heavy material in the
streets of the village, by throwing or letting the same fall upon the pavement
of any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public way, without first placing some
sufficient protection over the pavement.
(Prior Code, § 96.16) Penalty, see §
96.99
§ 96.17 MATERIALS ENCUMBERING STREET OR SIDEWALK.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to encumber any street or sidewalk, or,
being the owner, occupant, or person having the care of any building or lot of
land, bordering on any street or sidewalk, to permit the same to be encumbered
with barrels, boxes, cans, articles, or substances of any kind, so as to
interfere with the free and unobstructed use thereof.
(Prior Code, § 96.17) Penalty, see §
96.99
§ 96.18 REMOVAL OF SNOW AND ICE.
   (A)   The owner, occupant, or person having the care of any building or lot
of land bordering on any street with graded or paved sidewalk, within the first
four hours after daylight, following or during a fall of snow, shall cause the
snow to be removed from such walk; and this provision shall include snow or ice
falling from any building.
   (B)   Whenever such sidewalk or any part thereof shall become encumbered
with ice, the owner, occupant, or person in control, within the first four
hours after daylight, following or during its formation, shall cause such
sidewalk to be made safe by removing such ice or sprinkling the same with sand
or other suitable substance.
(Prior Code, § 96.18) Penalty, see §
96.99
EXCAVATIONS
§ 96.30 OPENING PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Any person, company, business, utility, corporation, or other entity,
desiring to open a village street, road, alley, or highway, shall first obtain
a permit to do so from the office of the Village Administrator. Each applicant
shall complete and file with the Village Administrator an application, on forms
provided by the village, along with a non-returnable application fee and a
security as set forth in §
96.32.
(Prior Code, § 96.30) (Ord. 97-10, passed 4-1-1997) Penalty, see §
96.99
§ 96.31 APPLICATION FEES.
   The application fees for a permit to open and close a village street, road,
alley, or highway, which fees shall be non-returnable, are as follows:
   (A)   A surface opening measuring up to, and including, 16 square feet:
$200; and
   (B)   For each additional four square feet of surface, or fraction thereof:
$40.
(Prior Code, § 96.31) (Ord. 97-10, passed 4-1-1997)
§ 96.32 SECURITY DEPOSIT.
   (A)   A security deposit shall also be submitted with each application for a
permit to open and close a village street, road, alley, or highway, which
deposit shall be retained to secure compliance with the requirements of such
permit, as follows:
      (1)   A surface opening measuring up to, and including 16 square feet:
$250; and
      (2)   For each additional four square feet of surface, or fraction
thereof: $50.
   (B)   All unused portions of the security deposit shall be returned to
applicant within 90 days from completion of the project.
(Prior Code, § 96.32) (Ord. 97-10, passed 4-1-1997; Ord. 05-18, passed 6-7-
2005)
§ 96.33 BACKFILLING REQUIRED.
   All openings, after completion of the necessary work or repairs, shall be
closed by applicant by backfilling in accordance with the following minimum
specifications:
   (A)   Suitable backfill material, which material must be pre-approved by the
Village Administrator, shall be granular in nature, and it shall be compacted
under and around the conduit in layers not to exceed eight inches in thickness.
Such compaction shall be performed with mechanical tampers or hand tampers; and
   (B)   The remaining portion of the opening shall be backfilled as follows.
      (1)   During the months of April through October, inclusive, the opening
shall be backfilled with compacted sand up to 13 inches from the surface,
followed by nine inches of concrete. The remaining four inches shall be
asphalt, which shall be and remain flush with the surface.
      (2)   During the months of December through March, inclusive, the opening
shall be backfilled with compacted sand up to nine inches from the surface. The
remaining nine inches shall then be filled with concrete up to and flush with
the surface.
(Prior Code, § 96.33) (Ord. 97-10, passed 4-1-1997) Penalty, see §
96.99
§ 96.34 ADMINISTRATION.
   The Village Administrator shall supervise the opening and closing, including
backfilling, of village streets, roads, alleys, and highways, at all times.
(Prior Code, § 96.34) (Ord. 97-10, passed 4-1-1997)
SIDEWALKS, CURBS, AND GUTTERS
§ 96.45 ESTABLISHMENT OF GRADE; SPECIFICATIONS.
   Whenever the Village Council decides to provide for the construction or
repair of any specific sidewalks, curbings or gutters, or parts thereof, other
than by special assessments, it shall require the Village Administrator to
proceed as follows.
   (A)   To establish the line and grade to be adhered to in such construction
work: If the grade of the sidewalk, curbings, or gutters is already
established, such repair or new construction shall conform therewith, unless a
new or different grade is desired. The grade in all cases shall refer to the
elevation of the top or upper surface of the existing or contemplated curb.
      (1)   If no grade has previously been established, or if a change of
grade is contemplated, the Village Administrator shall cause such grade to be
established or re-established and monumented with line and grade stakes, and
shall cause plats to be prepared and filed in his or her office indicating such
line and grade as established in outline and profile with the intersecting lot
lines, frontages, and the names and addresses of all abutting owners. Unless
otherwise provided, the upper surface of a sidewalk shall be approximately
level with the grade at every point.
      (2)   In all cases where a new or different grade is established, the
Administrator shall notify each owner who will be affected thereby, by written
notice of such establishment or change in grade, and of the fact that plats
have been prepared and are on file in his or her office, subject to the owner’s
inspection. Such notices shall be served on all residents of the village in the
manner provided by law for the service of summons in a civil action with a copy
thereof to be returned to said Administrator endorsed by the officer or person
serving it stating the time and manner of service. Service on non-residents and
persons not found may be made in the manner provided in R.C. §§ 729.03 and
729.04.
      (3)   At any time within ten days following completion of service of said
notice, any such owner shall have the right of appeal of such order of
establishment or change of grade to the Village Council, which shall hear such
appeal and render its decision by majority vote, which shall be final.
   (B)   If or after the grade for such improvement has been established, the
Administrator shall prepare and cause to be filed in his or her office, plans
and specifications for the construction or repair contemplated, setting forth
clearly the scope of the work, with full dimensions, the type quality and
quantity of materials and workmanship required, methods of construction to be
employed and such other matters as may be appropriate.
(Prior Code, § 96.50) Penalty, see §
96.99
§ 96.46 RESOLUTION OF COUNCIL; NOTICE TO OWNER.
   The Village Council by resolution may approve all or any sectional part of
such plans and specifications, and order the construction or repair of such
specified sidewalks, curbing, or gutters. A written notice of the passage of
such resolution shall be given to owner or agent of the owner of each parcel of
land abutting upon said improvement in the manner provided by law.
(Prior Code, § 96.51)
§ 96.47 PERMIT FOR WORK REQUIRED.
   No person other than the Village Administrator or his or her authorized
employees or agents shall construct or repair any sidewalk, curbing, or gutter
without first procuring a permit from the Village Administrator so to do. The
fee for each permit shall be $5.
(Prior Code, § 96.52) Penalty, see §
96.99
§ 96.48 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; REQUIREMENTS.
   Each application for a permit shall be made in writing by the person
employed to do the work, specifying the work to be done, and shall be signed by
the applicant and the owner or owners.
(Prior Code, § 96.53)
§ 96.49 APPLICANT’S QUALIFICATIONS; BOND REQUIRED.
   Each applicant for a permit shall be experienced and qualified in the
opinion of the Village Administrator to do the work contemplated in full
accordance with the village’s requirements. Applicants shall give bond in an
amount to be determined by the Administrator, but in no case less than $500 for
new construction, or $100 for repair work, with sufficient surety, conditioned
that said applicant will fully indemnify the village and save it harmless from
loss or drainage occasioned to it, directly or indirectly, from any act or
omission in the performance of any such work, and that he or she will replace
and restore to their pre-existing condition any portion of the street,
curbings, sidewalks, or other village owned or controlled property which may be
disturbed or interfered with by him or her in such construction.
(Prior Code, § 96.54)
§ 96.50 SUPERVISION OF CONSTRUCTION OR REPAIR; FINAL APPROVAL.
   Upon granting of a permit for the construction of said improvement, said
permittee shall proceed immediately with the improvement contemplated by the
resolution of the Village Council referred to in §
96.46; and shall complete the same without unnecessary delay. The Village
Administrator shall supervise the construction or repair and shall see that
said work has been faithfully performed according to plans and specifications
before final approval.
(Prior Code, § 96.55)
§ 96.51 PROCEEDINGS MAY INCLUDE DIFFERENT OWNERS.
   In all proceedings pertaining to the construction or repair of sidewalks,
curbs, or gutters under R.C. §§ 729.01 through 729.08, sidewalks, curbs, or
gutters upon different streets abutting upon lots or lands owned by different
owners may be included in the same resolution, notice, contract, ordinance, or
other proceedings.
(Prior Code, § 96.56)
Statutory reference:
   Generally, see R.C. § 729.05
RAILROADS
§ 96.65 RAILROAD TRAINS NOT TO BLOCK STREETS.
   No railroad or railway corporation or the directing officers thereof, or
operator of a train of railroad cars shall unnecessarily obstruct or prevent
the use of any public street within the village by permitting a railroad car or
cars, a locomotive or locomotives, or a railroad train to remain so close to a
railroad crossing that the automated street traffic control gates are closed or
to remain upon or across such public street, for longer than ten minutes to the
hindrance or inconvenience of travelers, or a person or vehicles passing along
or upon such public street. It shall likewise be unlawful for any railroad
train to stop within any intersection or on a crosswalk for the purpose of
receiving or discharging passengers or cargo.
(Prior Code, § 96.65) (Ord. 1995, passed 6-21-1966) Penalty, see §
96.99
Statutory reference:
   Generally, see R.C. § 729.65
§ 96.66 SPEED LIMIT FOR RAILROAD CARS.
   No railroad or railway corporation or the directing officers thereof or
operator of a train of railroad cars shall operate or cause to be operated, a
railroad car or cars, a locomotive or locomotives, at a speed in excess of 30
mph within the corporate limits of the village.
(Prior Code, § 96.66) (Ord. 1996, passed 6-21-1966) Penalty, see §
96.99
§ 96.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Whoever violates any provisions of this chapter, for which another
penalty is not already provided, shall be fined not more than $100.
   (B)   Whoever violates §
96.30 is guilty of unauthorized opening of a village street, which is a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
(Prior Code, § 96.99) (Ord. 97-10, passed 4-1-1997; Ord. 05-18, passed 6-7-
2005)

COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES
§ 110.01 LICENSE REQUIRED; COMPLIANCE WITH RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   No person, firm, association, club, society, or corporation shall operate,
conduct, or maintain a public place where pinball machines, coin-operated pool
tables, or other coin-operated amusement devices, excepting jukeboxes or coin-
operated music devices, are permitted to be placed, unless the person, firm,
association, club, society, or corporation has first obtained a license from
the Fiscal Officer. The license shall be issued subject to the rules and
regulations set forth in this chapter, but no license shall be granted to any
person under the age of 18 years.
(Prior Code, § 110.01) (Ord. 86-9, passed 1-22-1986; Ord. 08-08, passed 2-19-
2008) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 110.02 ANNUAL LICENSE FEE.
   The annual license fee for the license shall be $125 for each location,
regardless of the number of machines or devices placed at such location.
(Prior Code, § 110.02) (Ord. 86-9, passed 1-22-1986; Ord. 98-16, passed 5-7-
1998; Ord. 09-11, passed 7-7-2009)
§ 110.03 RECORDS TO BE KEPT; PAYMENT OF FEES.
   The Fiscal Officer shall keep a record of all licenses issued, and shall
place them to the credit of the General Fund.
(Prior Code, § 110.04) (Ord. 86-9, passed 1-22-1986; Ord. 08-08, passed 2-19-
2008)
§ 110.04 INSPECTION OF MACHINES AND PREMISES.
   All such machines or devices, and all premises in which said machines or
devices are maintained or exhibited, shall be open to inspection by the police
at all times.
(Prior Code, § 110.05) (Ord. 86-9, passed 1-22-1986) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 110.05 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   The Fiscal Officer, within his or her discretion, may revoke any license, or
suspend it for not more than 30 days if the licensee is convicted of operating
or maintaining such machine or device in violation of any of the provisions of
this subchapter.
(Prior Code, § 110.06) (Ord. 86-9, passed 1-22-1986; Ord. 08-08, passed 2-19-
2008)
PLACES OF PUBLIC ENTERTAINMENT
§ 110.15 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   PLACE OF PUBLIC ENTERTAINMENT. Every theater, moving picture theater, drive-
in theater, concert hall, auditorium, stadium, ball park, dance hall, dance
pavilion, or other building or place of entertainment charging a fee for
admission and for which a license is not required elsewhere in this code.
(Prior Code, § 110.20)
§ 110.16 LICENSE REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS.
   Every person desiring to operate or maintain a place of public entertainment
as defined in §
110.15, shall obtain a license before engaging in such business and shall pay
therefor the annual license fee of $25. However, no license or license fee
shall be required of any such establishment not operated for profit which is
owned and controlled by public school or college or by the village, county, or
the state, or by a private club exclusively for the use of its members.
(Prior Code, § 110.21) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 110.17 SCHEDULE OF ESTABLISHED PRICES.
   A schedule showing the complete scale of established prices shall be posted
in a conspicuous place in view of persons at the ticket window or other place
where tickets are on sale. It shall be unlawful to sell any ticket at a price
in excess of the established price appearing on such schedule.
(Prior Code, § 110.22) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 110.18 PLACES SHALL BE OPEN TO INSPECTION.
   Places of public entertainment shall be open to official inspection by the
County Health Department and members of the Police and Fire Departments at all
times, and all laws, ordinances, and safety rules and regulations shall be
strictly observed by the owner or operator of such business at all times.
(Prior Code, § 110.23) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 110.19 DANCES OR PUBLIC ENTERTAINMENT.
   Each person not the proprietor of a licensed dance hall, or dance pavilion,
desiring to conduct a public dance or similar form of entertainment for which
an admission charge is demanded or received, shall first obtain a license and
pay the license fee provided in §
110.16.
(Prior Code, § 110.24) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 110.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter for which
another penalty has not been provided, shall be fined not more than $100 for
each offense.
   (B)   No person, firm, association, club, society, or corporation shall
violate any provisions of §§
110.01 through
110.05. Whoever violates any provisions of these sections shall be fined not
more than $500 for each offense. Each day’s violation shall constitute a
separate offense.
(Prior Code, § 110.99) (Ord. 86-8, passed 1-22-1986)

AUCTIONEERS
§ 111.01 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   AUCTIONEER. Any person who engages in the business of selling or offering
for sale, personal property of any kind, to the highest bidder at public
auction, vendue, or outcry; excepting a fiduciary, officer, or other person
acting under or by virtue of a judicial or statutory order, process, or
authority; a vendor of chattels or merchandise which he or she desires to sell
at public auction and which are not acquired by him or her for the purpose of
sale at auction; and excepting the vendor of any product of his or her own
raising, or manufacture by himself or herself; any bona fide organization
conducting an auction, the proceeds from which are to be used for charitable or
religious purposes.
(Prior Code, § 111.01) (Ord. 1904, passed 2-5-1963)
§ 111.02 LICENSE REQUIRED; FEES.
   Every auctioneer shall obtain a license from the Mayor before engaging in
such business with the territorial limits of the village and shall pay
therefore an annual license fee in the amount of $35.
(Prior Code, § 111.02) (Ord. 1904, passed 2-5-1963) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.03 STATE LICENSE AND BOND REQUIRED.
   Every auctioneer, as a condition to obtaining a license hereunder, shall
furnish proof with his or her application that he or she has posted bond in the
sum of $1,000 with a County Treasurer, and has a license or licenses required
under the provisions of state law applicable to his or her said business.
(Prior Code, § 111.03) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.04 LICENSE ONLY LAID FOR THE SALE OF USED MERCHANDISE.
   The license provided for in §
111.02 shall be valid only for the sale of used merchandise. It shall be
unlawful for any auctioneer acting under such license to sell any new
merchandise of any kind or description.
(Prior Code, § 111.04) (Ord. 1904, passed 2-5-1963) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.05 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   Any violation by the auctioneer or his or her associates or employees of the
provisions of this subchapter or any other ordinances of the village, upon
conviction thereof, shall be cause for the Mayor to revoke the license provided
for in this subchapter in addition to the other penalties provided for in this
code of ordinances.
(Prior Code, § 111.05) (Ord. 1904, passed 2-5-1963)
AUCTION OF JEWELRY
§ 111.15 LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   Any person desiring to conduct or engage in the sale for gain at public
auction of jewelry, including solid or plated platinum, gold, or silver pieces,
or imitations thereof, precious, semi-precious, or synthetic jewels or
imitations thereof, with or without settings, watches and chains, rings, pins,
necklaces, bracelets, earrings, or other similar articles of ornamentation or
utility, shall first obtain a jewelry auction license, and pay the fee of $25.
Each license shall terminate automatically at the end of the period for which
it is issued, which shall not exceed 30 days.
(Prior Code, § 111.15) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.16 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   The following information shall be furnished in addition to that required of
licensees generally:
   (A)   The length of time in which the applicant has been engaged in the
jewelry business and location of his or her place or places of business. No
applicant shall be eligible unless he or she has been engaged in the jewelry
business for at least one year immediately preceding his or her application,
and unless he or she has maintained a bona fide jewelry store in the village
for the preceding three months;
   (B)   Names and addresses of the auctioneers, each of whom shall be duly
licensed by the village as auctioneers, who will cry the merchandise;
   (C)   Time, dates, and place of holding such auction; and
   (D)   An itemized list or inventory of each article of jewelry to be offered
for sale, with date of purchase and name and address of person from whom it was
purchased.
(Prior Code, § 111.16)
§ 111.17 INDEMNITY BOND.
   In addition to the filing of the application and payment of the license fee,
each applicant as a condition to obtaining a license shall post a bond with
good and sufficient surety in the sum of $2,500, conditioned to indemnify any
purchaser at such auction against loss due to misrepresentation of any article
sold.
(Prior Code, § 111.17)
§ 111.18 EACH ARTICLE TO BE LABELED.
   Each article of jewelry offered for sale shall bear a tag, label, or stamp,
accurately describing the kind, quality, and percent of purity of the metal,
stone, or other composition thereof, and accurately stating whether it is
solid, overlaid or plated, genuine, synthetic or imitation, new, or secondhand,
and the true name or names of the manufacturers where known.
(Prior Code, § 111.18) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.19 RECORDS TO BE KEPT.
   A complete record of all sales made at such auction shall be kept open to
inspection by purchasers and village authorities with the names and addresses
of the purchaser of each item and the price paid.
(Prior Code, § 111.19) Penalty, see §
111.99
JUNK DEALERS
§ 111.30 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   JUNK. Any personal property which is or may be salvaged for re-use, re-sale,
reduction, or similar disposition, or which is possessed, transported, owned,
collected, accumulated, dismantled, or assorted for any of the aforesaid
purposes. Used household furniture, used wearing apparel, used lumber, used
brick, used tile, used plumbing fixtures, used electrical fixtures, used
articles made of precious metal or metals, used jewelry, used tools, and other
used articles of personal property and which are not handled as what are
usually called junk as used herein. Without limiting the aforesaid definition
of JUNK, the term shall include used or salvaged iron, brass, copper, and other
base metal or metals, and their compounds or combinations; used or salvaged
rope, paper, rags, glass, rubber, and similar articles, or property, and used
motor vehicles which are used, owned, or possessed for the purpose of wrecking
or salvaging parts therefrom.
   JUNK DEALER. Every person who buys, exchanges, collects, receives, stores,
or sells any article or articles herein above defined as junk.
   JUNK YARD or JUNK SHOP. Any place at which a junk dealer buys, exchanges,
collects, receives, stores, accumulates, sells, or otherwise handles junk.
   PERSON. A firm, corporation, or individual person.
(Prior Code, § 111.30) (Ord. 1495, passed 7-5-1949)
§ 111.31 LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION FOR LICENSE TO BE APPROVED BY CHIEF OF
FIRE DEPARTMENT.
   No person shall maintain or operate a junk shop or junk yard in the village
unless he or she has at first obtained a license therefor. Applications for
such license shall be made to the Chief of the Fire Department, upon such
blanks as shall be prescribed by the Chief, and upon approval of said
application by the Chief, a license shall be issued by the Mayor as provided
for herein. In making the aforesaid application, the applicant shall state his
or her name, whether a person, firm, or corporation, the place or places at
which such business is to be conducted or maintained, and any further
information as may be required by the Chief.
(Prior Code, § 111.31) (Ord. 1495, passed 7-5-1949) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.32 LICENSE FEE.
   Any person, firm, or corporation being the owner of a junk shop or any
person, firm, or corporation before engaging in the junk business within the
village shall pay to the Mayor a license fee in the sum of $25 per annum, and
all such licenses shall be for a period of one year. A license fee shall be
required for each place at which applicant maintains a junk yard or junk shop.
The aforesaid license fee shall not be prorated. All licenses shall expire on
January 15.
(Prior Code, § 111.32) (Ord. 1495, passed 7-5-1949) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.33 PREMISES TO BE ENCLOSED BY FENCE.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate a junk yard
or junk shop within the village unless such business is carried on entirely
inside a building or buildings, or unless the premises upon which such business
is carried on be entirely enclosed by a solid built fence at least six feet in
height, and such fence must be approved by the Chief of the Fire Department.
Such fence shall be maintained in a neat, substantial, safe condition, and
shall be painted. Gates for access to the said premises shall swing inwardly,
and such gates shall be kept closed when the premises are not open for
business.
   (B)   No junk shall be stored in the village unless the same be in a
building or enclosed yard. Such junk, whether in a building or in an enclosed
yard, shall be so piled or placed that adequate passageways are open.
(Prior Code, § 111.33) (Ord. 1495, passed 7-5-1949) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.34 CONDITION OF PREMISES.
   All premises used as junk yard or junk shop shall be kept in as clean,
sanitary, and neat condition as such business will reasonably permit. The
person operating the junk yard or junk shop shall maintain the premises so used
so that rats, vermin, and fire hazard are as far as practicable reduced to a
minimum. No rubbish or portions or parts of wrecked machines and other
accumulations which are to be discarded by such junk dealer shall be burned on
such premises without the written consent of the Chief of the Fire Department.
(Prior Code, § 111.34) (Ord. 1495, passed 7-5-1949) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.35 INSPECTION OF PREMISES.
   It shall be the duty of the Chief of the Fire Department to inspect or cause
to be inspected at least once every three months all the junk yards or junk
shops in the village. Such inspection shall be for the purpose of seeing that
such premises are operated in conformity with this subchapter and are kept in a
safe and sanitary condition.
(Prior Code, § 111.35) (Ord. 1495, passed 7-5-1949)
§ 111.36 RECORDS MUST BE KEPT BY DEALERS.
   All persons, firms, and corporations so licensed and so engaged in the junk
business shall keep in its place of business a book, books, or ledger in which
shall be kept and numbered consecutively an accurate record of each purchase
setting forth a description of the articles, goods, and merchandise purchased
and the time of receiving the same, together with the name and address of the
person selling or delivering such goods purchased by the dealer.
(Prior Code, § 111.36) (Ord. 1495, passed 7-5-1949) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.37 ENFORCEMENT.
   It shall be the duty of the Chief of the Fire Department to enforce the
terms and conditions of this subchapter.
(Prior Code, § 111.37) (Ord. 1495, passed 7-5-1949)
§ 111.99 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm, or corporation engaged in the junk business as a dealer,
or any employee of such dealer who shall be convicted in a court of competent
jurisdiction of violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty
of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than $100 and pay the costs of
prosecution for the first offense; and for each subsequent offense, shall be
fined not less than $100 and not more than $300, and may be imprisoned not more
than 30 days or both, and pay the costs of prosecution.
(Prior Code, § 111.99) (Ord. 1495, passed 7-5-1949)
CHAPTER 112: BULK MATERIALS
Section
   
112.01   Purpose
   
112.02   Definitions
   
112.03   Imposition of fee
   
112.04   Bulk Materials Transport Fund
   
112.05   Periodic review of fee amount
   
112.06   Forms for monthly manifest report
   
112.07   Delinquency, penalties, and interest
 
   
112.99   Penalty
§ 112.01 PURPOSE.
   The general purpose of this chapter is to provide the public health, safety,
and welfare of the residents of the village by generating funds not for general
revenue purposes but for the sole purpose of producing sufficient funds to
provide certain services provided by the village. These services include, but
are not limited to, providing road construction, maintenance, and repair for
the transportation of bulk materials from such areas within the village;
providing extraordinary police and fire protection services to monitor and
respond to emergency calls related to the transportation of bulk materials;
providing liability insurance for the village for potential future claims
against the village resulting from the transportation of bulk materials from
various facilities located within the village; and providing engineering,
legal, and other professional services necessary to monitor the transportation
and shipping of bulk materials from various facilities located within the
village.
(Ord. 17-14, passed 8-1-2017)
§ 112.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BULK MATERIALS.
      (1)   Any material that is ordered, stored, issued, and sold by weight,
that includes, but is not limited to, material transported and unpackaged in
large.
      (2)   All definitions of BULK MATERIALS shall be the same, but not
limited to, the definitions contained in the Ohio Revised Code.
   FACILITY. Any site, location, tract of land, installation, or building used
for transportation and/or shipping of bulk materials.
   MANIFEST. The form used for identifying the quantity, weight, composition,
origin, routing, and destination of bulk materials during the transportation
from the point of shipping to the point of destination.
(Ord. 17-14, passed 8-1-2017)
§ 112.03 IMPOSITION OF FEE.
   (A)   There is hereby imposed a permit fee on all bulk materials transported
or shipped within, to, and from the village.
   (B)   In the case of bulk materials, the fee shall be in the amount of $0.20
per ton transported. The fee shall be paid monthly to the Fiscal Officer based
upon the municipal corporation limits according to the shipping manifests or
other transportation records and such other methods of determining tonnage as
may be agreed upon by the village and the transporter/shipper. Such permit fee
shall be paid by the twenty-fifth day of each month following the calendar
month for which the report is filed.
(Ord. 17-14, passed 8-1-2017)
§ 112.04 BULK MATERIALS TRANSPORT FUND.
   (A)   There is hereby created a fund known as the Bulk Materials Transport
Fund, which shall be the depository of all the fee proceeds generated from this
chapter.
   (B)   Such funds shall not be used for any general fund purpose of the
village, but shall be restricted solely to expenditure in order to protect the
public health, safety, and welfare of residents for expenses directly related
to the transportation, shipping, and receiving of bulk materials, including,
but not limited to, the following items:
      (1)   To provide sufficient funds in order to meet the specialized and
local cost of the village resulting from the transportation and proper
monitoring of the trucks utilizing the roadways to and from the bulk materials
shipping facilities;
      (2)   The cost of road construction, maintenance, and repair for the
weight of the trucks utilizing safe roads to and from the sites;
      (3)   The costs of necessary insurance premiums for liability insurance
for the village for potential future claims against the village resulting from
the transportation of bulk materials;
      (4)   The cost of engineering, legal, and other professional services
necessary to monitor the transportation of bulk materials; and
      (5)   The cost incurred by the village to carry out the provisions of
this chapter.
(Ord. 17-14, passed 8-1-2017)
§ 112.05 PERIODIC REVIEW OF FEE AMOUNT.
   Village Council, on or before December 31, 2017 and on or before December 31
of each odd year thereafter, shall make a review of all expenditures made from
the Bulk Materials Transportation Fund during the preceding year in order to
determine if such fee amounts should be increased, decreased, or remain the
same so that sufficient funds are generated in order to protect the public
health, safety, and welfare of the residents. Such funds shall not exceed the
amount necessary to carry out the specific purposes set out in this chapter,
but shall be sufficient to cover all costs incurred in the administration of
this chapter by carrying out the purposes set forth herein.
(Ord. 17-14, passed 8-1-2017)
§ 112.06 FORMS FOR MONTHLY MANIFEST REPORT.
   Each operator or shipper of any bulk materials located within the village
shall keep complete accurate records and manifests of the amount, type, and
volume of bulk materials shipped and received each day. Such records shall be
provided to the Fiscal Officer and the monthly remittance of permit fee along
with such form shall be filed with the Fiscal Officer on or before the twenty-
fifth day of each month for the previous month’s report.
(Ord. 17-14, passed 8-1-2017)
§ 112.07 DELINQUENCY, PENALTIES, AND INTEREST.
   (A)   Original delinquency. Any transporter or shipper who fails to remit
any fee imposed by this chapter within the time required shall pay a penalty
equal to 10% of the amount of the fee, in addition to the fee.
   (B)   Continued delinquency. Any transporter or shipper who fails to remit
any delinquent remittance on or before a period of 30 days following the date
on which the remittance first became delinquent shall pay a second delinquency
penalty equal to 10% of the amount of the fee and 10% of the amount of the fee,
and 10% of the total fee and penalty of the previous 30-day period shall be
added for each successive 30-day period that the operator remains delinquent.
   (C)   Fraud. If the non-payment of any remittance under this chapter is due
to fraud, a penalty equal to 25% of the amount of the fees shall be added
thereto in addition to the penalties stated in divisions (A) and (B) of this
section.
   (D)   Interest. In addition to the previous penalties imposed, any operator
who fails to remit any fees imposed by this chapter shall pay interest at the
rate of 1.5% per month, or fraction thereof, on the amount of the fees,
exclusive of penalties, from the date on which the remittance first became
delinquent until paid.
(Ord. 17-14, passed 8-1-2017)
§ 112.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any provisions of this chapter
shall be fined not more than $1,000 or imprisoned not more than six months or
both.
(Ord. 17-14, passed 8-1-2017)
CHAPTER 113: GARBAGE AND REFUSE DISPOSAL BY PRIVATE HAULERS
Section
   
113.01   Definitions
   
113.02   Licenses
   
113.03   Investigation of applicant
   
113.04   Loads dropping or leaking
   
113.05   Collection times
   
113.06   Revocation of license
   
113.07   Deposit of loads
 
   
113.99   Penalty
§ 113.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and
their derivations shall have the meanings given herein, and the word “shall” is
always mandatory and not merely directive.
   GARBAGE. Putrescible animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling,
preparation, cooking, and consumption of food.
   HAULER. Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or
organization of any kind licensed to collect refuse and/or garbage in the
village.
   MAYOR. The Mayor of the Village of Wellsville, Ohio.
   PERSON. Any person, firm, partnership, association, company, corporation, or
organization of any kind.
   REFUSE. Paper, barrels, boxes, baskets, wood, rags, mattresses, worn-out
small furniture, old shoes, leather, carpets, broken glass, crockery, tin cans,
rubber, ashes, and similar discarded materials. It does not, however, include
any material in the nature of earth, sand, brick, stone, plaster, or other
substances that may accumulate as a result of building operations.
   VILLAGE. The Village of Wellsville, Ohio.
(Prior Code, § 117.01) (Ord. 06-30, passed 7-18-2006)
§ 113.02 LICENSE.
   (A)   No person shall engage in the business of hauling garbage and/or
refuse within the village corporate limits unless he or she shall first obtain
a license therefor from the Mayor.
   (B)   Council hereby determines that it would be for the best interest of
the village not to issue more than three such licenses within the corporate
limits of the village for the hauling of garbage and/or refuse. By reason
thereof, the Mayor is hereby limited to issuing not more than three licenses
for the hauling of garbage and/or refuse.
   (C)   The Mayor shall collect a fee of $500 for each garbage and/or refuse
hauling license, as issued under the provision of this chapter, which fee or
fees shall be for the calendar year for which said license or licenses are
issued.
(Prior Code, § 117.02) (Ord. 06-30, passed 7-18-2006) Penalty, see §
113.99 
§ 113.03 INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT.
   The Mayor shall investigate each application to determine the suitability of
such applicant to render the service of a hauler. At the time of application,
the applicant shall furnish and file with the Mayor the following: Written
proof of a policy or policies of liability insurance issued for the life of the
license applied for, or longer, by a responsible insurance company, approved as
to the sufficiency by the Mayor, and providing indemnity for, or protection to
the applicant against loss resulting from the operation of each vehicle to the
extent of $1,000,000 combined single limit for bodily injury and property
damage, and list on the policy the village as an additional named insured; and
provide to the village written proof of a general commercial liability policy
with limits of $1,000,000 for each occurrence, and a $2,000,000 aggregate.
(Prior Code, § 117.03) (Ord. 06-30, passed 7-18-2006) Penalty, see §
113.99 
§ 113.04 LOADS DROPPING OR LEAKING.
   Any truck used in the collection of garbage and/or refuse shall be so
constructed and operated that its contents do not spill or scatter over any
public or private property, and shall visibly display the name of the licensed
hauler on the truck. Any person hauling any garbage and/or refuse in any open
vehicle, such as a truck or trailer, shall provide that the load thereof be
covered with an adequate tarpaulin or canvas so as to prevent any spillage or
scattering of its contents.
(Prior Code, § 117.04) (Ord. 06-30, passed 7-18-2006) Penalty, see §
113.99 
§ 113.05 COLLECTION TIMES.
   The collection times for the pick-up of garbage and/or refuse shall be
between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on Monday through Friday and 6:00
a.m until 12:00 noon on Saturday. No collection will be permitted on Sunday.
(Prior Code, § 117.05) (Ord. 06-30, passed 7-18-2006) Penalty, see §
113.99 
§ 113.06 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   The license required by this chapter may be revoked by the Mayor if the
holder thereof violates any of the provisions or regulations of this chapter,
of any duly constituted Department of Health, or of any law or statute of the
state.
(Prior Code, § 117.06) (Ord. 06-30, passed 7-18-2006)
§ 113.07 DEPOSIT OF LOADS.
   No garbage and/or refuse shall be deposited by the holder of a hauler’s
license within the corporate limits of the village or elsewhere, except at a
duly licensed landfill.
(Prior Code, § 117.07) (Ord. 06-30, passed 7-18-2006) Penalty, see §
113.99 
§ 113.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed
guilty of a minor misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an
amount not exceeding $100; each day such violation is committed or permitted to
continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such
hereunder.
(Prior Code, § 117.99) (Ord. 06-30, passed 7-18-2006)
CHAPTER 114: INTOXICATING LIQUOR
Section
   
114.01   Possession of open container of intoxicating liquor in certain places
prohibited
   
114.02   Consumption of beer or intoxicating liquor in motor vehicle
   
114.03   Purchase, consumption or possession of intoxicating liquor or beer by
underage persons prohibited
 
   
114.99   Penalty
§ 114.01 POSSESSION OF OPEN CONTAINER OF INTOXICATING LIQUOR IN CERTAIN PLACES
PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No person shall have in his or her possession an opened container of
intoxicating liquor in a state store or on the premises of the holder of any
permit issued by the Department of Liquor Control, or in any public place.
   (B)   This section shall not apply to intoxicating liquor which has been
lawfully purchased for consumption on the premises or bought of a holder of an
A-1-A, A-2, D-2, D-3, D-3A, D-4, D-5, and D-5A permit.
(Prior Code, § 112.01) (Ord. 82-5, passed 8-17-1982) Penalty, see §
114.99
§ 114.02 CONSUMPTION OF BEER OR INTOXICATING LIQUOR IN MOTOR VEHICLE.
   No person shall consume any beer or intoxicating liquor in a motor vehicle.
(Prior Code, § 112.02) (Ord. 82-14, passed 8-17-1982) Penalty, see §
114.99
§ 114.03 PURCHASE, CONSUMPTION, OR POSSESSION OF INTOXICATING LIQUOR OR BEER BY
UNDERAGE PERSONS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No person under the age of 21 years shall purchase beer or
intoxicating liquor.
   (B)   No person under the age of 21 years shall order, pay for, share the
cost of, or attempt to purchase any beer or intoxicating liquor, or consume any
beer or intoxicating liquor, either from a sealed or unsealed container, or by
the glass or by the drink, or possess any beer or intoxicating liquor, in any
public or private place.
(Prior Code, § 112.03) (Ord. 91-11, passed 3-19-1991; Ord. 91-12, passed 3-19-
1991) Penalty, see §
114.99
§ 114.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating §
114.01 shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
   (B)   Any person violating §
114.02 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
   (C)   Whoever violates §
114.03(A) is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree.
   (D)   Whoever violates §
114.03(B) is guilty of a minor misdemeanor, and shall be fined not less than
$25, nor more than $100. On a second offense, or any subsequent offense,
violation of §
114.03(B) shall be a misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
(Prior Code, § 112.99) (Ord. 82-5, passed 8-17-1982; Ord. 82-14, passed 8-17-
1982; Ord. 91-11, passed 3-19-1991; Ord. 91-12, passed 3-19-1991)
CHAPTER 115: MERCHANTS PROVIDING SERVICES OR PRODUCTS
Section
Cigarettes or Tobacco Products
